It belongs to the family Asclepiadaceae and is characterized by its thick, fleshy stems and waxy, glossy leaves. The plant produces clusters of star-shaped, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring or early summer. Hoya polilloensis is well adapted to humid, shaded environments and requires well-draining soil to thrive. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
